description: Erection of single storey rear extension (6.0m in depth, maximum height of 3.4m and eaves height of 2.9m)
decision_conditions: The proposed extension together with the existing extension would extend beyond a wall forming a side elevation of the original dwellinghouse, and would have a width greater than half the width of the original dwellinghouse, in conflict with Paragraph A.1 (j) (iii) and (ja) of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended).

--- Officer Report ---IntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.The Development Plan comprises:The London Plan 2021;RBK Core Strategy 2012;Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008; and,The South London Waste Plan 2012.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Application SiteThe site comprises a public house. It is located in the Kingston Old Town Conservation a designated heritage asset.Consultation KTCAAC no objection but do comment on the signage to the right of entrance at front being too big.AssessmentThe application relates to the display of advertisements. The key considerations are AmenityPublic safetyAmenity The signage would be on the front and rear of the building. The site fronts High Street and at the rear faces onto the KIngston riverside and towpath. The building occupies a prominant position in both the street and riverscape and the existing signage is of a traditional wood finish. It is considered that the proposed finishes and illumination of the proposed signage would be a sympthetic addition to the host property and of a size proportionate to the facade of the host building. The signage whilst visible would not create visual clutter or be visually intrusive. The proposed signage would not detract from the character and appearance of the host property or cause harm to the designated heritage asset the Kingston Old Town Conservation Area as it would  preserve its overall character and appearance. Public safetyThe proposed signage would be static and would not obscure any highway signs or impede pedestrian movement. The proposed signage would not prejudice highway safety. ConclusionIn conclusion the proposed signage would accord with section 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990, paras 189 - 208 of the NPPF and policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Councils adopted LDF Core Strategy.Details of the Application SubmissionIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 details of the application submission were available on the Council's website during the assessment of the application.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal--- Informatives ---Positive and ProactiveIn dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.
